newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela sells 32.86 bln bolivars of TEM bills.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela sells 32.86 bln bolivars of TEM bills.

text.p: Venezuela's Central Bank said it sold 30 billion bolivars of 180-day "monetary stabilization", or TEM, bills at a price of 99.42 percent.
The 180-day bills carried a 32.76 percent coupon.

The bank also sold 1.0 billion bolivars of 269-day notes with a 34.05 percent coupon at a price of 97.87 percent, and 1.86 billion bolivars of 358-day notes with a 35.41 percent coupon at an average price of 97.58 percent.
The bank had offered 30 billion bolivars of 180-day notes, 10 billion of 269-day notes, and 10 billion of 358-day notes.

According to a preliminary calculation by Reuters using the Central Bank's method, the yield on the notes was 34.12 percent for the 180-day TEMs, 37.71 percent on the 269-day notes, and 38.79 percent for the 358-day TEMs.
At last week's auction, the bank sold 177-day bills with a tield of 32.71 percent.
The weekly TEM bill auctions are the Central Bank's principal tool of monetary policy, used to restrict liquidity and establish a benchmark for wider interest rates.
